cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
Who first drew Mickey Mouse when ?Disney first supplied the voice?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
1. To determine who first drew Mickey Mouse, we need to look into the history of the character's creation. Mickey Mouse was created by Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks. Ub Iwerks is credited with the actual design and animation of Mickey Mouse in his early appearances.
2. The first appearance of Mickey Mouse was in the short film "Steamboat Willie," which premiered on November 18, 1928. This date is significant as it marks the official debut of Mickey Mouse.
3. Regarding the voice of Mickey Mouse, Walt Disney himself provided the voice for the character in the early years. He voiced Mickey Mouse starting from the character's first appearance in "Steamboat Willie."

Answer:
Ub Iwerks first drew Mickey Mouse in 1928, and Walt Disney first supplied the voice in the same year, during "Steamboat Willie."

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
Who first drew Mickey Mouse when ?Disney first supplied the voice?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Born in Chicago in 1901, Disney developed an early interest in drawing. He took art classes as a boy and got a job as a commercial illustrator at the age of 18. He moved to California in the early 1920s and set up the Disney Brothers Studio with his brother Roy. With Ub Iwerks, Walt developed the character Mickey Mouse in 1928, his first highly popular success; he also provided the voice for his creation in the early years. As the studio grew, Disney became more adventurous, introducing synchronized sound, full-color three-strip Technicolor, feature-length cartoons and technical developments in cameras. The results, seen in features such as "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" (1937), "Pinocchio", "Fantasia" (both 1940), "Dumbo" (1941), and "Bambi" (1942), furthered the development of animated film. New animated and live-action films followed after World War II, including the critically successful "Cinderella" (1950) and "Mary Poppins" (1964), the latter of which received five Academy Awards.\n', 'Mickey Mouse himself appeared in every show, not only in vintage cartoons originally made for theatrical release, but also in the opening, interstitial, and closing segments made especially for the show. In both the vintage cartoons and new animated segments, Mickey was voiced by his creator Walt Disney. (Disney had previously voiced the character theatrically from 1928 to 1947 before being replaced by sound effects artist Jimmy MacDonald.)\n', 'Originally temporary, the production team incorporated archival recordings of Walt Disney\'s Mickey Mouse voice from 1928 to 1947, and spliced it into the character\'s dialogue. However, they did not find recordings of some words, including the word "red", so the crew took three sounds, a "rrr", a "ehh", and a "duh" from Disney\'s recordings and spliced them together.\n', 'Disney had provided the voice for Mickey Mouse since his debut in 1928, and "Fun and Fancy Free" was the last time he would voice the role regularly, as he no longer had the time or energy to do so. Disney recorded most of Mickey\'s dialogue in the spring and summer of 1941. Sound effects artist Jimmy MacDonald would become the character\'s new voice actor, starting in 1948. Disney, however, did reprise the role for the introduction to the original 1955–59 run of "The Mickey Mouse Club".\n', 'Walt Disney did the voice of Mickey Mouse for the first three episodes. Starting with the fourth episode, Mickey was voiced by comedian Joe Twerp. Disney appeared as himself in some early episodes. In later episodes, Disney was too busy to attend performances, and he was impersonated by announcer John Hiestand. Radio actor J. Donald Wilson provided the voice for one episode.\n', 'Minnie was first voiced by Walt Disney, who was also the original voice of Mickey Mouse. Marjorie Ralston, a Disney inker who joined the animation team as Disney\'s thirteenth employee, voiced her in the 1929 short "Wild Waves", but did not further pursue the role out of shyness. Then, from 1930 until 1939, she was voiced by Marcellite Garner. Then from 1941 to 1942, and on the radio program, "The Mickey Mouse Theater of the Air", she was voiced by Thelma Boardman. Following this, from 1942 to 1952 Ruth Clifford provided the character\'s voice. Janet Waldo voiced Minnie in the 1974 Disneyland record album, "An Adaptation of Dickens\' Christmas Carol, Performed by The Walt Disney Players". Minnie Mouse would go without any spoken dialogue until 1986, when Russi Taylor inherited the role, which she performed until her death in 2019 (her husband, Wayne Allwine, voiced Mickey from 1977 until his death in 2009).\n', 'BULLET::::- Minnie Mouse (voiced by Walt Disney through 1928 to 1929, Marjorie Ralston through 1929, Marcellite Garner through 1929 to 1939, Thelma Boardman through 1939 to 1942, Ruth Clifford through 1942 to 1952, Janet Waldo through 1974, and Russi Taylor through 1986 to present) – is a funny animal cartoon character created by Ub Iwerks and Walt Disney. She and Mickey Mouse were first drawn by Ub Iwerks in 1928. The comic strip story "The Gleam" (published January 19–May 2, 1942) by Merrill De Maris and Floyd Gottfredson first gave her full name as Minerva Mouse, although this is seldom used.\n', 'John James MacDonald (May 19, 1906 – February 1, 1991) was a Scottish-born American foley artist, animator, voice actor, musician, and the original head of the Disney sound effects department. He was also the voice of Mickey Mouse from 1947 to 1977.\n', "BULLET::::- Mickey Mouse (voiced by Walt Disney through 1928 to 1947, Carl W. Stalling through 1929, Clarence Nash through 1934, Jimmy MacDonald through 1947 to 1977, Wayne Allwine through 1977 to 2009, Les Perkins through 1986 to 1987, Bret Iwan through 2009 to present, and Chris Diamantopoulos through 2013 to present) – is a funny animal cartoon character and the mascot of The Walt Disney Company. He was created by Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks at the Walt Disney Studios in 1928. An anthropomorphic mouse who typically wears red shorts, large yellow shoes, and white gloves, Mickey is one of the world's most recognizable characters.\n", 'Disney voice actor and sound effects editor Wayne Allwine voiced Mickey Mouse in the animated lead-ins for the show, replacing Jimmy MacDonald, who in 1947 had replaced Walt Disney as the voice of Mickey for theatrical cartoons. Walt Disney had been the original voice of Mickey and for the original 1954—1959 run provided the voice for animated introductions to the original TV show but had died in 1966. Allwine kept providing the voice for the character up to his death in 2009.\n']

   - The passages clarify that **Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks** were the creators of Mickey Mouse, with Iwerks being the one who physically drew the character. 2. **When Disney First Supplied the Voice**:
   - The information indicates that **Walt Disney provided the voice for Mickey Mouse starting from his debut in 1928**. 3. **Evolution of the Character**:
   - The passages also mention that Disney continued to voice Mickey until 1947, after which Jimmy MacDonald took over. ### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

1. **Identifying the Creators**:
   - Mickey Mouse was created collaboratively by **Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks** in **1928**. While both were instrumental in the character's development, **Ub Iwerks** is credited with the actual drawing and animation of Mickey Mouse's early appearances. This highlights the collaborative nature of animation during that era.

2. **Significance of the Debut**:
   - The character made his official debut in the animated short film **"Steamboat Willie,"** which premiered on **November 18, 1928**. This date is significant as it marks the first public introduction of Mickey Mouse, establishing him as a cultural icon.

3. **Voice of Mickey Mouse**:
   - **Walt Disney** provided the voice for Mickey Mouse starting from his debut in **1928**. This means that Disney not only co-created the character but also gave him his voice from the very beginning. He continued to voice Mickey until **1947**, after which **Jimmy MacDonald** took over the role. This transition reflects the increasing demands on Disney's time as his studio expanded.

4. **Historical Context**:
   - Walt Disney had a strong background in art, having developed an early interest in drawing and taking art classes as a child. He, along with his brother **Roy Disney**, established the **Disney Brothers Studio**, which later became the Walt Disney Company. This context is essential for understanding the environment in which Mickey Mouse was created.

5. **Cultural Impact**:
   - Mickey Mouse is not just a character; he represents a significant milestone in the history of animation and popular culture. His creation marked the beginning of a new era in animated films, showcasing innovations such as synchronized sound and character-driven storytelling.

### Conclusion:
The enhanced reasoning process provides a comprehensive understanding of the origins of Mickey Mouse, including the roles of both Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks, the significance of the character's debut, and the historical context surrounding its creation. This understanding is crucial for accurately answering the question about who first drew Mickey Mouse and when Disney first supplied the voice.

### Answer:
**Ub Iwerks first drew Mickey Mouse in 1928, and Walt Disney first supplied the voice in the same year, during "Steamboat Willie."**

Mickey Mouse was created by **Walt Disney** and **Ub Iwerks** at the Walt Disney Studios in **1928**. Iwerks is credited with the actual design and animation of Mickey Mouse, making him a pivotal figure in the character's visual identity.

2. **First Appearance**: The character made his official debut in the short film **"Steamboat Willie,"** which premiered on **November 18, 1928**. This date is significant not only as the character's first appearance but also as a landmark moment in animation history, being one of the first cartoons to feature synchronized sound.

3. **Voice of Mickey Mouse**: Walt Disney provided the voice for Mickey Mouse from his debut in **1928** until **1947**. This establishes Disney's integral role not only as the creator but also as the original voice actor, contributing to the character's personality and charm during its formative years.

### Answer:
**Ub Iwerks first drew Mickey Mouse in 1928, and Walt Disney first supplied the voice in the same year, during "Steamboat Willie."** This collaboration marked the inception of one of the most iconic characters in animation history, with Disney's voice acting contributing significantly to Mickey's charm and popularity.

Janet Waldo voiced Minnie in the 1974 Disneyland record album, "An Adaptation of Dickens' Christmas Carol, Performed by The Walt Disney Players". Minnie Mouse would go without any spoken dialogue until 1986, when Russi Taylor inherited the role, which she performed until her death in 2019 (her husband, Wayne Allwine, voiced Mickey from 1977 until his death in 2009).
', 'BULLET::::- Minnie Mouse (voiced by Walt Disney through 1928 to 1929, Marjorie Ralston through 1929, Marcellite Garner through 1929 to 1939, Thelma Boardman through 1939 to 1942, Ruth Clifford through 1942 to 1952, Janet Waldo through 1974, and Russi Taylor through 1986 to present) – is a funny animal cartoon character created by Ub Iwerks and Walt Disney. She and Mickey Mouse were first drawn by Ub Iwerks in 1928. The comic strip story "The Gleam" (published January 19–May 2, 1942) by Merrill De Maris and Floyd Gottfredson first gave her full name as Minerva Mouse, although this is seldom used.
', 'John James MacDonald (May 19, 1906 – February 1, 1991) was a Scottish-born American foley artist, animator, voice actor, musician, and the original head of the Disney sound effects department. He was also the voice of Mickey Mouse from 1947 to 1977.
', "BULLET::::- Mickey Mouse (voiced by Walt Disney through 1928 to 1947, Carl W. Stalling through 1929, Clarence Nash through 1934, Jimmy MacDonald through 1947 to 1977, Wayne Allwine through 1977 to 2009, Les Perkins through 1986 to 1987, Bret Iwan through 2009 to present, and Chris Diamantopoulos through 2013 to present) – is a funny animal cartoon character and the mascot of The Walt Disney Company. He was created by Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks at the Walt Disney Studios in 1928. An anthropomorphic mouse who typically wears red shorts, large yellow shoes, and white gloves, Mickey is one of the world's most recognizable characters.
", 'Disney voice actor and sound effects editor Wayne Allwine voiced Mickey Mouse in the animated lead-ins for the show, replacing Jimmy MacDonald, who in 1947 had replaced Walt Disney as the voice of Mickey for theatrical cartoons. Walt Disney had been the original voice of Mickey and for the original 1954—1959 run provided the voice for animated introductions to the original TV show but had died in 1966. Allwine kept providing the voice for the character up to his death in 2009.
']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages regarding the creation of Mickey Mouse and the voice provided by Walt Disney. Here’s a summary of the key points:

1. **Creation of Mickey Mouse**:
   - Mickey Mouse was developed by Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks in 1928.
   - Ub Iwerks was instrumental in the character's design and animation.

2. **Walt Disney's Role**:
   - Walt Disney not only co-created Mickey Mouse but also provided the character's voice from 1928 until 1947.
   - Disney's voice work for Mickey included recordings made in the spring and summer of 1941, and he continued to voice the character for various projects until 1947.

3. **Transition of Voice**:
   - After 1947, Disney was replaced by sound effects artist Jimmy MacDonald as the voice of Mickey Mouse.
   - Disney reprised his role for specific projects, such as the introduction to "The Mickey Mouse Club" in the 1950s.

4. **Historical Context**:
   - The character of Mickey Mouse became a significant cultural icon and was featured in various media, including vintage cartoons and television shows.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference

1. **Understanding Relationships**:
   - The information establishes a clear causal relationship between the collaboration of Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks in creating Mickey Mouse and the subsequent popularity of the character. This helps the model understand how collaborative efforts can lead to successful outcomes.

2. **Temporal Sequencing**:
   - The timeline of events (creation in 1928, voice work until 1947, and the transition to a new voice actor) provides a framework for the model to understand the sequence of events and their implications. This is crucial for logical reasoning, as it allows the model to infer the consequences of actions over time.

3. **Role of Individuals**:
   - By identifying the roles of different individuals (Disney as creator and voice actor, Iwerks as animator), the model can better understand how individual contributions impact collective success. This enhances the model's ability to reason about the significance of roles in collaborative projects.

4. **Cultural Impact**:
   - The recognition of Mickey Mouse as a cultural icon illustrates the broader implications of creative work. The model can learn to infer that successful characters or creations can lead to significant cultural phenomena, which is a valuable insight for understanding the impact of creative industries.

5. **Voice Transition**:
   - The transition of voice actors and the reasons behind it (Disney's increasing workload) can help the model understand the dynamics of creative roles and the importance of continuity in character representation. This can enhance the model's reasoning about how changes in personnel can affect a brand or character's identity.

In summary, the extracted information provides a rich context for understanding the causal relationships and logical sequences involved in the creation and evolution of Mickey Mouse. This can significantly improve the model's ability to reason about similar scenarios in creative and collaborative contexts.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.
question:
Who first drew Mickey Mouse when ?Disney first supplied the voice?
answer:
Reasoning process:
1. To determine who first drew Mickey Mouse, we need to look into the history of the character's creation. Mickey Mouse was created by Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks. Ub Iwerks is credited with the actual design and animation of Mickey Mouse in his early appearances.
2. The first appearance of Mickey Mouse was in the short film "Steamboat Willie," which premiered on November 18, 1928. This date is significant as it marks the official debut of Mickey Mouse.
3. Regarding the voice of Mickey Mouse, Walt Disney himself provided the voice for the character in the early years. He voiced Mickey Mouse starting from the character's first appearance in "Steamboat Willie."

Answer:
Ub Iwerks first drew Mickey Mouse in 1928, and Walt Disney first supplied the voice in the same year, during "Steamboat Willie."

This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.

When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.

['Born in Chicago in 1901, Disney developed an early interest in drawing. He took art classes as a boy and got a job as a commercial illustrator at the age of 18. He moved to California in the early 1920s and set up the Disney Brothers Studio with his brother Roy. With Ub Iwerks, Walt developed the character Mickey Mouse in 1928, his first highly popular success; he also provided the voice for his creation in the early years. As the studio grew, Disney became more adventurous, introducing synchronized sound, full-color three-strip Technicolor, feature-length cartoons and technical developments in cameras. The results, seen in features such as "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" (1937), "Pinocchio", "Fantasia" (both 1940), "Dumbo" (1941), and "Bambi" (1942), furthered the development of animated film. However, they did not find recordings of some words, including the word "red", so the crew took three sounds, a "rrr", a "ehh", and a "duh" from Disney\'s recordings and spliced them together.\n', 'Disney had provided the voice for Mickey Mouse since his debut in 1928, and "Fun and Fancy Free" was the last time he would voice the role regularly, as he no longer had the time or energy to do so. Janet Waldo voiced Minnie in the 1974 Disneyland record album, "An Adaptation of Dickens\' Christmas Carol, Performed by The Walt Disney Players". He was also the voice of Mickey Mouse from 1947 to 1977.\n', "BULLET::::- Mickey Mouse (voiced by Walt Disney through 1928 to 1947, Carl W. Stalling through 1929, Clarence Nash through 1934, Jimmy MacDonald through 1947 to 1977, Wayne Allwine through 1977 to 2009, Les Perkins through 1986 to 1987, Bret Iwan through 2009 to present, and Chris Diamantopoulos through 2013 to present) – is a funny animal cartoon character and the mascot of The Walt Disney Company. He was created by Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks at the Walt Disney Studios in 1928. An anthropomorphic mouse who typically wears red shorts, large yellow shoes, and white gloves, Mickey is one of the world's most recognizable characters.\n", 'Disney voice actor and sound effects editor Wayne Allwine voiced Mickey Mouse in the animated lead-ins for the show, replacing Jimmy MacDonald, who in 1947 had replaced Walt Disney as the voice of Mickey for theatrical cartoons. Walt Disney had been the original voice of Mickey and for the original 1954—1959 run provided the voice for animated introductions to the original TV show but had died in 1966. Allwine kept providing the voice for the character up to his death in 2009.\n']

question_info.question: Who first drew Mickey Mouse when ?Disney first supplied the voice?
passages:
Born in Chicago in 1901, Disney developed an early interest in drawing. He took art classes as a boy and got a job as a commercial illustrator at the age of 18. He moved to California in the early 1920s and set up the Disney Brothers Studio with his brother Roy. With Ub Iwerks, Walt developed the character Mickey Mouse in 1928, his first highly popular success; he also provided the voice for his creation in the early years. As the studio grew, Disney became more adventurous, introducing synchronized sound, full-color three-strip Technicolor, feature-length cartoons and technical developments in cameras. The results, seen in features such as "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" (1937), "Pinocchio", "Fantasia" (both 1940), "Dumbo" (1941), and "Bambi" (1942), furthered the development of animated film. New animated and live-action films followed after World War II, including the critically successful "Cinderella" (1950) and "Mary Poppins" (1964), the latter of which received five Academy Awards.
Mickey Mouse himself appeared in every show, not only in vintage cartoons originally made for theatrical release, but also in the opening, interstitial, and closing segments made especially for the show. In both the vintage cartoons and new animated segments, Mickey was voiced by his creator Walt Disney. (Disney had previously voiced the character theatrically from 1928 to 1947 before being replaced by sound effects artist Jimmy MacDonald.)
Originally temporary, the production team incorporated archival recordings of Walt Disney's Mickey Mouse voice from 1928 to 1947, and spliced it into the character's dialogue. However, they did not find recordings of some words, including the word "red", so the crew took three sounds, a "rrr", a "ehh", and a "duh" from Disney's recordings and spliced them together.
Disney had provided the voice for Mickey Mouse since his debut in 1928, and "Fun and Fancy Free" was the last time he would voice the role regularly, as he no longer had the time or energy to do so. Disney recorded most of Mickey's dialogue in the spring and summer of 1941. Sound effects artist Jimmy MacDonald would become the character's new voice actor, starting in 1948. Disney, however, did reprise the role for the introduction to the original 1955–59 run of "The Mickey Mouse Club".
Walt Disney did the voice of Mickey Mouse for the first three episodes. Starting with the fourth episode, Mickey was voiced by comedian Joe Twerp. Disney appeared as himself in some early episodes. In later episodes, Disney was too busy to attend performances, and he was impersonated by announcer John Hiestand. Radio actor J. Donald Wilson provided the voice for one episode.
Minnie was first voiced by Walt Disney, who was also the original voice of Mickey Mouse. Marjorie Ralston, a Disney inker who joined the animation team as Disney's thirteenth employee, voiced her in the 1929 short "Wild Waves", but did not further pursue the role out of shyness. Then, from 1930 until 1939, she was voiced by Marcellite Garner. Then from 1941 to 1942, and on the radio program, "The Mickey Mouse Theater of the Air", she was voiced by Thelma Boardman. Following this, from 1942 to 1952 Ruth Clifford provided the character's voice. Janet Waldo voiced Minnie in the 1974 Disneyland record album, "An Adaptation of Dickens' Christmas Carol, Performed by The Walt Disney Players". Minnie Mouse would go without any spoken dialogue until 1986, when Russi Taylor inherited the role, which she performed until her death in 2019 (her husband, Wayne Allwine, voiced Mickey from 1977 until his death in 2009).
BULLET::::- Minnie Mouse (voiced by Walt Disney through 1928 to 1929, Marjorie Ralston through 1929, Marcellite Garner through 1929 to 1939, Thelma Boardman through 1939 to 1942, Ruth Clifford through 1942 to 1952, Janet Waldo through 1974, and Russi Taylor through 1986 to present) – is a funny animal cartoon character created by Ub Iwerks and Walt Disney. She and Mickey Mouse were first drawn by Ub Iwerks in 1928. The comic strip story "The Gleam" (published January 19–May 2, 1942) by Merrill De Maris and Floyd Gottfredson first gave her full name as Minerva Mouse, although this is seldom used.
John James MacDonald (May 19, 1906 – February 1, 1991) was a Scottish-born American foley artist, animator, voice actor, musician, and the original head of the Disney sound effects department. He was also the voice of Mickey Mouse from 1947 to 1977.
BULLET::::- Mickey Mouse (voiced by Walt Disney through 1928 to 1947, Carl W. Stalling through 1929, Clarence Nash through 1934, Jimmy MacDonald through 1947 to 1977, Wayne Allwine through 1977 to 2009, Les Perkins through 1986 to 1987, Bret Iwan through 2009 to present, and Chris Diamantopoulos through 2013 to present) – is a funny animal cartoon character and the mascot of The Walt Disney Company. He was created by Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks at the Walt Disney Studios in 1928. An anthropomorphic mouse who typically wears red shorts, large yellow shoes, and white gloves, Mickey is one of the world's most recognizable characters.
Disney voice actor and sound effects editor Wayne Allwine voiced Mickey Mouse in the animated lead-ins for the show, replacing Jimmy MacDonald, who in 1947 had replaced Walt Disney as the voice of Mickey for theatrical cartoons. Walt Disney had been the original voice of Mickey and for the original 1954—1959 run provided the voice for animated introductions to the original TV show but had died in 1966. Allwine kept providing the voice for the character up to his death in 2009.
